citations.narrative:
The licensee is not using the required APHIS Form 7006 for disposition records for puppies and does not have an
approved variance. The licensee is currently using a required form from the state of Ohio for the sale of puppies to pet
stores. Nine puppies have been sold in 2024 and documented on this Ohio form and not on the required 7006 form per
2.75 (a)(2). The use of APHIS Form 7006 is required as it allows for proper traceability and management of regulated
animals at a facility.
Each dealer shall use Record of Disposition of Dogs and Cats (APHIS Form 7006) to make, keep, and maintain the
information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section. Provided, that if a dealer or exhibitor who uses a computerized
recordkeeping system believes that APHIS Form 7006 are unsuitable for him or her to make, keep, and maintain the
information required by paragraph (a)(1) of this section, the dealer or exhibitor may request a variance from the
requirement to use APHIS Form 7006. Correct by ensuring all required information is fully and correctly documented on
an APHIS Form 7006 or by obtaining a variance.
Correct by 19 September 2024

The medical records for two adult dachshunds “Fido” (USDA Tag 017) DOB 12/27/2023 and “Spotty” (USDA Tag 018)
DOB 2/12/2024 show the dogs have not been vaccinated for rabies. The Program of Veterinary Care states dogs will be
vaccinated for rabies at 16 weeks and then annually going forward. The licensee currently has the veterinarian administer
the rabies vaccine. Failure to follow the preventative care schedule for vaccinations in the Program of Veterinary Care
does not ensure the dogs are receiving appropriate protection against contagious and deadly diseases such as rabies
which can lead to illness and discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the vaccination schedule approved by the
attending veterinarian in the Program of Veterinary Care to protect the dogs from deadly or contagious diseases including
rabies.
The facility has not performed the annual fecal testing for internal parasites and was unable to provide documentation of
the last date of sampling. The Program of Veterinary Care states fecal exams will be performed annually and as needed
but does not state a specific number or percentage of the animal population indicating all dogs in the facility should be
tested annually. Failure to follow the parasite control program approved by the Attending Veterinarian may not properly
protect the dogs from parasites and may cause illness to go undetected and untreated, which may cause pain and
unnecessary discomfort to the dogs. The facility must follow the parasite control testing schedule approved by the
attending veterinarian to protect the dogs from parasites and other pests (worms, coccidia, giardia and heartworm) and
have the dogs tested annually.
Correct by 10 October 2024

The licensee is not following an appropriate program of veterinary care to prevent healthy and un-matted hair coats.
Two female Maltese adult dogs “Maggie” (USDA Tag 007) and “Daisy” (USDA Tag 014) were observed with multiple large
areas of matted fur in the rump area, hind limbs, and lower forelimbs. “Daisy” additionally was observed with matted fur on
her face with the matted fur extending over her right eye. The skin under the matted areas appeared normal with no signs
of redness or irritation and neither dog vocalized or appeared in discomfort when manipulating the matted areas. The fur
in the matted areas had yellow/brown discoloration likely from urine or feces.
Matted fur may cause discomfort, pain, skin irritation, or can lead to infection. The licensee must follow an appropriate
preventative care and treatment plan to ensure healthy and un-matted hair coats to support the health and well-being of
the dogs.
To be corrected by: 26 September 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representative.
